content: Physical AI represents the integration of artificial intelligence algorithms with physical systems. Unlike traditional AI that operates in virtual environments, Physical AI must navigate the complexities of the real world including physics, sensorimotor coordination, and environmental interactions.

learning_outcomes: Understand the fundamental concepts of Physical AI
Distinguish between traditional AI and Physical AI
Identify key applications of Physical AI in robotics

content: The field of Physical AI has evolved from early robotics research to modern embodied intelligence systems. Key milestones include the development of sensorimotor learning, advances in control theory, and the integration of deep learning with physical systems.

learning_outcomes: Understand the fundamental concepts of Physical AI
Distinguish between traditional AI and Physical AI
Identify key applications of Physical AI in robotics

content: Sensorimotor coordination is fundamental to Physical AI. It involves the continuous cycle of perception, decision-making, and action. In humanoid robotics, this loop must operate in real-time to enable stable locomotion, manipulation, and interaction with the environment.

Embodied cognition emphasizes that intelligence emerges from the interaction between an agent's body, environment, and control system. Morphological computation refers to the idea that the physical properties of a body can simplify computational tasks.

learning_outcomes: Analyze the role of morphology in intelligence

content: Applying reinforcement learning to physical systems presents unique challenges including safety constraints, sample efficiency, and sim-to-real transfer. This section covers techniques for safe exploration and efficient learning in physical domains.

learning_outcomes: Implement reinforcement learning for physical systems

content: This section covers the major humanoid robot platforms including Honda's ASIMO, Boston Dynamics' Atlas, SoftBank's Pepper, and research platforms like the NAO and HRP-4. Each platform offers different capabilities and trade-offs between mobility, manipulation, and computational power.

Bipedal locomotion is one of the most challenging aspects of humanoid robotics. This section covers the dynamics of walking, including center of mass control, foot placement, and balance maintenance during gait transitions.

Humanoid robots require sophisticated manipulation capabilities to interact with objects in their environment. This section covers grasping strategies, force control, and dexterous manipulation techniques.

Humanoid robots are designed to interact with humans in social contexts. This section covers the principles of social robotics, including non-verbal communication, emotional expression, and social norms.

Sim-to-real transfer is crucial for Physical AI, allowing policies learned in simulation to work in the real world. This section covers domain randomization, system identification, and reality gap minimization techniques.

Physics-informed neural networks (PINNs) incorporate physical laws directly into the learning process. This approach ensures that learned models respect fundamental physical constraints such as conservation of energy and momentum.

learning_outcomes: Understand conservation laws in neural networks

content: Embodied learning systems learn through physical interaction with their environment. This section covers curiosity-driven exploration, intrinsic motivation, and self-supervised learning in physical systems.

learning_outcomes: Evaluate learning progress in physical systems

content: Multiple physical AI agents can coordinate to achieve complex tasks. This section covers communication protocols, distributed control, and emergent behaviors in multi-robot systems.

Physical AI is increasingly used in manufacturing for tasks requiring dexterity, adaptability, and human-robot collaboration. This section covers applications in assembly, quality control, and flexible manufacturing.
Service robots assist humans in daily tasks, from domestic chores to healthcare support. This section covers navigation, manipulation, and human-robot interaction in service applications.

chapter: Safety and Ethics in Physical AI
content: Safety is paramount in Physical AI systems that operate in close proximity to humans. This section covers safety standards, fail-safe mechanisms, and risk assessment in physical AI applications.

learning_outcomes: Analyze safety considerations in Physical AI

content: The field of Physical AI continues to evolve with new research directions including neuromorphic physical systems, bio-hybrid robots, and quantum-enhanced physical AI. This section explores these emerging areas.

learning_outcomes: Identify emerging trends in Physical AI
